title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #976: For irreducible f ∈ ℤ[x] of degree d ≥ 2, let F_f(n) = greatest prime dividing ∏_{m=1}^n f(m). Is F_f(n) ≫ n^{1+c} or even n^d? The main conjectures remain OPEN. Best known: F_f(n) ≫ n·exp((log n)^c) by Tenenbaum (1990).

title: Irreducible Polynomial
content: A polynomial f ∈ ℤ[x] is irreducible if it has degree ≥ 1 and cannot be factored into polynomials of smaller degree over ℤ. Examples: x² + 1, x² - 2, x³ - 2. This is analogous to prime numbers among integers.

title: Greatest Prime Divisor
content: P(n) = max{p prime : p | n}. For example, P(60) = 5 since 60 = 2² · 3 · 5. By convention P(1) = 1. This function measures the 'smoothness' of an integer - smooth numbers have small P(n).

title: The Function F_f(n)
content: F_f(n) = greatest prime dividing f(m) for any 1 ≤ m ≤ n. Equivalently, F_f(n) = P(∏_{m=1}^n f(m)). This captures the largest prime factor appearing in the first n polynomial values.

title: Nagell-Ricci Bound (1922)
content: F_f(n) ≫ n log n for any irreducible f of degree ≥ 2. This was the first non-trivial lower bound, establishing that F_f(n) grows faster than linear. The proof uses elementary number theory.

title: Erdős Bound (1952)
content: F_f(n) ≫ n(log n)^{log log log n}. Erdős improved Nagell-Ricci using sieve methods to count integers with large prime factors. The iterated logarithm exponent shows slow but unbounded growth beyond n log n.

title: Tenenbaum Bound (1990)
content: F_f(n) ≫ n·exp((log n)^c) for some c > 0. Currently the best rigorous bound. The exp((log n)^c) factor grows faster than any power of log but slower than any power of n - a 'sub-polynomial' improvement.

title: First Conjecture
content: Conjecture: F_f(n) ≫ n^{1+c} for some c > 0. This would establish true polynomial growth, vastly stronger than current bounds. The gap between n·exp((log n)^c) and n^{1+c} is enormous.

title: Second Conjecture
content: Stronger conjecture: F_f(n) ≫ n^d where d = deg(f). This says the degree of the polynomial controls the growth exponent. Would imply quadratics give n², cubics give n³, etc.

title: Linear Case
content: For degree 1 polynomials f(x) = ax + b, the problem reduces to prime factors in arithmetic progressions. By Dirichlet's theorem, primes appear infinitely often, giving F_f(n) ~ n. The problem is only interesting for d ≥ 2.

title: Quadratic Case
content: For f(x) = x² + 1, prime divisors p | m² + 1 must satisfy p ≡ 1 (mod 4) or p = 2, connecting to Gaussian primes. The Chebotarev density theorem governs which primes divide polynomial values.

title: Example: x² - 2
content: For f(x) = x² - 2, a prime p divides m² - 2 for some m iff 2 is a quadratic residue mod p, which by quadratic reciprocity means p ≡ ±1 (mod 8). This illustrates the algebraic constraints on divisors.

title: Sieve Methods
content: Sieve methods count integers with specific prime factor properties. Erdős used them to show polynomial products must have large prime factors. The key: among n integers, not all can be 'smooth' (have only small prime factors).

title: Large Sieve
content: Tenenbaum's proof uses the large sieve inequality, a powerful tool in analytic number theory. It bounds sums over 'well-spaced' subsets and is crucial for estimating exponential sums over prime divisors.

title: Algebraic Connection
content: Prime divisors of f(m) relate to prime splitting in the number field K = ℚ[x]/(f). A prime p divides f(m) for some m iff p splits completely or partially in K. This algebraic structure constrains which primes appear.

title: Chebotarev Density
content: The Chebotarev density theorem: primes splitting in a given way in K have positive density determined by the Galois group of f. This ensures infinitely many primes divide polynomial values, but doesn't give growth rates.

title: The Lost Proof
content: In 1965, Erdős claimed F_f(n) ≫ n·exp((log n)^c) but called the proof 'fairly complicated' and never published it. Later the proof was found to be flawed. Erdős-Schinzel 1990 published a weaker bound, apparently unaware of the issue.

title: Current Status
content: Erdős #976 is OPEN for the main conjectures. Known: F_f(n) ≫ n·exp((log n)^c). Conjectured: n^{1+c} or n^d. The gap is huge - resolving this would be a major breakthrough in analytic number theory.
